Regulating the hydroformylation capacity of heterogeneous catalysts is essential for efficiently converting higher olefins into aldehydes. In this study, a magnetic single-atom rhodium-cobalt-based catalyst (RhCo SACs) was synthesised by modifying Fe3O4 with polymerised carbon nitride. Maintaining a constant metal single-atom loading, the catalytic activity in 1-dodecene hydroformylation was modulated by adjusting the type of N species in the support. The distribution of single atoms and valence states was characterised. At the same time, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to evaluate substrate binding energies and reaction-free energy barriers, providing insights into reaction mechanisms and pathways. The RhCo-pyridinic N configuration lowered the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining and hydrogenation steps, enhancing substrate reaction activity. Compared to RhCo-graphitic N, RhCo-pyridinic N demonstrated superior performance, achieving a 1-dodecene conversion rate of 98.3 % and aldehyde selectivity of 98.6 %. Furthermore, the catalyst was magnetically recovered without loss of activity or mass and maintained stable performance over 10 reuse cycles. These findings present a novel and efficient strategy for the precise design of magnetic single-atom catalysts with potential practical applications in the hydroformylation of high-carbon olefins. This reaction demonstrates 100 % atom economy, with aldehyde products serving as key intermediates in the synthesis of high-value bulk fine chemicals such as alcohols, esters, and amines [1–3]. The petrochemical industry generates significant quantities of C12 or higher high-carbon olefin by-products, which are converted via hydroformylation into aldehydes or alcohols with improved economic efficiency. However, hydroformylation of these high-carbon olefins presents greater challenges due to increased steric hindrance from their extended chain structures, which affects the interaction between the substrate and the catalyst’s active site. Consequently, the structural design requirements for catalysts are more stringent. Hydroformylation reactions are conducted using homogeneous catalytic systems involving Rh or Co complexes with phosphine ligands [4–6]. Although these homogeneous catalysts offer high efficiency, their separation from the reaction medium remains a significant challenge. The complex catalyst separation, purification, and recovery processes substantially increase industrial costs. Additionally, these ligands are expensive, highly sensitive to air and moisture, susceptible to deactivation at elevated temperatures, and require meticulous handling. For high-carbon products with high boiling points, separation from the catalyst necessitates high-temperature flash evaporation, exacerbating catalyst decomposition and deactivation. Efficient catalyst recovery is, therefore, essential in the hydroformylation of high-carbon olefins. Heterogeneous hydroformylation offers a more economically viable and sustainable alternative, leading to increased interest in the development of efficient ligand-free heterogeneous catalysts [7,8]. Heterogeneous catalysts facilitate easier separation and reuse, significantly contributing to the economic and environmental sustainability of the hydroformylation process, making them a promising alternative, particularly for high-carbon olefin hydroformylation reactions [9]. Metal nanoparticles, nanoclusters, and supported metal nanoparticles have been explored as potential candidates for heterogeneous hydroformylation reactions, exhibiting reactivity toward various alkene substrates [10,11]. However, these heterogeneous catalysts face challenges primarily due to the low utilisation efficiency of metal active centres, limited catalytic activity, and reduced selectivity for oxygen-containing products, as side reactions such as hydrogenation and isomerisation of alkenes often occur. Reducing metal size to the atomic level enhances the surface atom ratio of active centres, thereby improving metal utilisation efficiency [12–14]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) provide an effective link between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, enabling highly utilised and uniformly dispersed metal species with homogeneous-like electronic states, facilitating the heterogenisation of homogeneous catalysts[15–17]. The atomic dispersion of metals and their local coordination environments play a crucial role in determining catalyst activity, selectivity, and stability. Investigating the structure-performance relationship of active centres with their supports, optimising the coordination environment on the support surface, and regulating metal-support interactions are essential for balancing catalyst stability and activity [18,19]. A rational structural design of SACs is necessary to enhance catalytic performance and support industrial applications [20–23]. For the structural design of single-atom catalysts, various metals (Pd, Ag, Pt, or Ir) are immobilised as isolated atoms onto supports such as metal oxides and activated carbon through two primary pathways: direct methods, including co-polymerisation and in-situ doping, and post-synthesis techniques like wet deposition and microwave-assisted treatments combined with chemical reduction [24–27]. The selection of the metal introduction method plays a critical role in determining the charge distribution around the metal centres embedded within the support matrix, a well-established phenomenon. Moreover, the accessibility and electronic properties of the adsorbed metal species can be regulated by modifying the morphology and porosity of the graphitic carbon nitride material [28,29]. Owing to their exceptional catalytic performance, rhodium-based single-atom catalysts (Rh-SACs) have emerged as a focal point in advanced catalyst design. Ro et al.[30] designed heteroatom Rh-ReOx by manipulating the local electronic environment of atomically dispersed Rh single sites. The targeted deposition of Rh precursors near atomically dispersed Lewis acidic ReOx on γ-Al2O3, promoted the concentration of vacant sites under reaction conditions and, in turn, catalytic activity. Prieto et al.[31] developed SACs with isolated Rh atoms stabilized on oxygen-defective SnO2. They modulate the direct coordination environment at SA sites via the exploitation of the surface chemistry of the oxide support. The catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the hydroformylation of ethylene. Zhang et al.[32] reported atomically dispersed bifunctional Rh and Co double-atom catalysts via the ball milling method. The catalyst exhibited superior synergistic catalytic performance in tandem hydroformylation/hydrogenation reactions (>95 % olefin conversion and >80 % alcohol selectivity). On this basis, single-atom catalysts utilizing magnetic carriers offer a combination of high catalytic efficiency and effective recovery capability [33,34]. Magnetic catalysis, widely recognised as an advanced technique, provides the distinct advantage of utilising magnetic fields to enable the rapid and highly efficient separation of catalysts from complex reaction systems [35,36]. This approach effectively addresses the persistent challenge of intricate separation and recovery procedures associated with conventional multiphase catalysts, significantly improving the economic feasibility and sustainability of the catalytic process. Consequently, the precise structural design and systematic optimisation of magnetic catalysts are essential to fully realising their potential [37]. Magnetic-supported single-atom catalysts with exceptional performance in high-carbon α-olefin hydroformylation are introduced. Modification of magnetic carriers with polymer carbon nitride effectively enhances the capture sites of active centres and achieves a high dispersion of single-atom metal active sites. By adjusting the type of N species to regulate metal-carrier interactions, the adsorption behaviour of CO and other substrate molecules was characterised using in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) to investigate the catalytic active site interactions. The results indicate that the RhCo-pyridine N mode facilitates the adsorption of substrate molecules on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the reaction pathway and mechanism of 1-dodecene hydroformylation were theoretically analysed through Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations. The simulations illustrate the role of different N species in the carrier in regulating the adsorption mode of reactants and their influence on catalyst activity and selectivity. The DFT findings suggest that adjusting the type of N-doping effectively regulates the electron density distribution of the loaded metal, thereby influencing the adsorption state of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface. The RhCo-pyridine N mode lowers the activation energy barriers of both pathways in the 1-dodecene hydroformylation reaction, facilitating the reaction process. Additionally, these catalysts exhibit excellent magnetic separation capability. Magnetic separation is readily achieved by applying an external magnetic field, significantly reducing catalyst loss. Cyclic experiments demonstrate that catalyst performance remains stable after 10 consecutive cycles, confirming its durability and potential for practical applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Rhodium chloride trihydrate (RhCl3·3H2O), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 98.5 %), hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), and iron(II,III) oxide were obtained from Aladdin. o-Phenylenediamine, aniline, and hydrogen peroxide were sourced from TCI, while the CO/H2 mixture (50:50 v/v) was supplied by DALIAN SPECIAL GASES CO., LTD. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthetic methods During the standard synthesis procedure, 5 g of Fe3O4 was combined with 0.5 g of o-phenylenediamine and 0.32 g of aniline in 200 mL of CTAB aqueous solution (10 mM), followed by the addition of 2.5 mL of 30 % hydrogen peroxide. After thorough mixing, the solution was stirred at 40 °C for 2 h to modify the surface of the magnetic Fe3O4 particles. The obtained solid was subsequently dispersed in 30 mL of distilled water containing RhCl3·3 H2O (300 ppm) and Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (200 ppm) and stirred for 20 h. The resulting product underwent heat treatment in a tubular furnace under an inert nitrogen atmosphere. Within the experimental range, the Rhodium (Rh) and Cobalt (Co) loadings were maintained consistently at 0.6 % and 0.2 %, respectively, which were relative to the total catalyst mass. The specimens were prepared using a segmented temperature-programmed method, with final heat treatment temperatures set at 500 °C, 650 °C, and 800 °C. The resulting samples were designated as RhCo/FCN-500 (FCN-500), RhCo/FCN-650 (FCN-650), and RhCo/FCN-800 (RhCo/FCN-800). For comparison, Rh/FCN-500 (without Co loading) and Co/FCN-500 (without Rh loading) were also prepared. For the naming convention of catalysts (FCN-X), “F” represents the magnetic carrier Fe3O4, “C” and “N” represent the surface of the carrier coated with a shell containing carbon and nitrogen, and “X” represents different treatment temperatures. O-Phenylenediamine and aniline are aromatic monomers that form a polymer skeleton and introduce N-functional groups; hydrogen peroxide is a free radical initiator that initiates the polymerization process; and hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) is a surfactant. CTAB self-assembled via charge effects to form a “soft template” and direct the growth of the polymer to form a better core-shell structure; Fe3O4 can catalyse the oxidation of aromatic monomers and promote polymer layer formation on its surface [38]. 2.3 Characterisation techniques HAADF-STEM images were obtained using a JEOL ARM-200 F field-emission transmission electron microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. TEM images were acquired with an FEI Talos F200x equipped with an EDS: Super X detector. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Bruker D8 diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted with a ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250Xi under a vacuum of 8 × 10–10 Pa, utilising Al Kα rays (hν = 1486.6 eV) as the excitation source. The charge shift was corrected by referencing all binding energies to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV. FTIR spectra were recorded using a NICOLET iS50 FT-IR spectrometer. The metal loadings were tested via inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) with a PE Avio 200 instrument. The mass contents of carbon and nitrogen were determined with a vario EL cube elemental analyser (Elementar). The metal dispersion was determined via a Micrometeric autochem 2920-hiden HPR20. In situ DRIFT experiments were performed using an elevated-pressure cell (DiffusIR Accessory PN 041–10XX) coupled with a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (TENSOR II Sample Compartment RT-DLaTGS) at 100 °C. The sample was first exposed to a flow of N2 at 1 atm and a rate of 30 sccm for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the background spectrum of the sample was recorded. The sample was subsequently treated with 1 atm of 5 % CO/He for at least 1 h, followed by the collection of DRIFT spectra post-treatment. For in situ heating experiments, the sample was heated to 130 °C, and a mixture of H2 and gaseous 1-dodecene was introduced into the cell for 1 h. In situ DRIFT spectra were then collected after exposure to different gases. 2.4 Catalytic tests The hydroformylation of 1-dodecene was conducted in a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave. A Teflon inlet containing 20 mL of 1-dodecene and the catalyst was placed inside the autoclave, which was then pressurised with a CO/H2 gas mixture (1:1) to 80 bar. For FCN-500, FCN-650, and FCN-800, the catalyst loading was maintained at 60 mg. The reaction was carried out at 90 °C with stirring at 300 rpm for 4 h. Upon completion, the liquid phase of the reaction mixture was separated using a magnet. The product composition was determined by GC-FID and further analysed by GC–MS using toluene as the internal standard. 2.5 DFT calculation All calculations in this study were conducted using the Dmol3 code integrated into the Materials Studio software [39]. The generalised gradient approximation with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA+PBE) functional was employed to describe exchange and correlation effects [40,41]. The core electrons were treated using the DFT semi-core pseudopotential (DSPP), and the Grimme DFT-D2 method was applied to account for dispersion interactions [42,43]. The double numerical plus polarisation (DNP) basis set with an atomic orbital basis of 4.4 was utilised [44]. The reciprocal space was sampled using a (2 × 2 × 1) k-point grid, generated automatically via the Monkhorst-Pack method for relaxation calculations [45]. Convergence tolerances for geometry optimisation were set at 10–5 Ha (1 Ha = 27.21 eV) for energy, 0.002 Ha/Å for maximum force, and 0.005 Å for maximum displacement. The electronic SCF tolerance was set to 10–6 Ha. A smearing of 0.005 Ha was applied to orbital occupations to enhance electronic convergence. Additionally, the complete linear synchronous transit (LST)/quadratic synchronous transit (QST) methods in the Dmol3 code were used to locate transition states (TS) [46]. To further interpret the experimental results, the qualitative effects of different N-doping types and Co metal atoms on Rh-catalysed 1-dodecene oxidation were investigated. Pyridine N, graphite N-doped graphene, and graphene models were constructed for supporting highly dispersed Rh/Co atoms, along with a single-atom Rh-loaded pyridine N-doped graphene model. For model construction, the bulk graphite structure was first optimised, followed by cutting along the (001) crystal plane to create a (7 × 7) supercell, yielding a monolayer graphene structure. The pyridine N and graphite N-doped graphene models were developed by selectively removing or replacing carbon atoms on the graphene surface. A 20 Å vacuum layer was introduced to prevent mirror image interactions between atomic layers. The adsorption energy of small molecules on the catalyst surface was determined using the following formula: (1) ∆ E molecular = E sur + molecular − E sur − E molecular where the E sur + molecular is the total energy of the surface model with the adsorbed small molecule, E sur denotes the total energy of the surface model, and E molecular corresponds to the energy of a single small molecule in a vacuum. The transition state energy barriers for each catalytic reaction were determined using Eq. 2: (2) ∆ E barrier = E TS − E IS where the E TS represents the total energy of the transition state structure, and E IS is the total energy of the initial state structure. Additionally, the charge density differences of the catalyst model were quantified using Perl scripting. 3 Discussion 3.1 Structural characterisation The morphology of the samples is presented in Fig. 1a and S1. The catalyst exhibits a typical core-shell structure, where magnetic Fe3O4 functions as the core, and an aromatic amine layer undergoes oxidative polymerisation on the outer surface to form a polymer coating. Nitrogen doping is incorporated through amino and imino groups. Following thermal treatment and carbonisation, the polymer layer is converted into a nitrogen-doped carbon layer, as illustrated in Fig. 1a. By adjusting the amount of aromatic amine and the reaction duration, the catalyst size distribution is effectively controlled within the range of 2–16 nm (Figure S2). High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images with spherical aberration correction are displayed in Fig. 1b. The circled regions in these images distinctly reveal the presence of individual Rh and Co metal atoms, demonstrating their high-density and uniform dispersion. The absence of metal particles or larger crystalline phases suggests the successful formation of atomically dispersed metal species. Additionally, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Fig. 1d-g) confirms the homogeneous distribution of N, Rh, and Co across the surface. An EDS line scan at the edge position further illustrates the element distribution in FCN-500, as shown in Figure S3. Collectively, these findings verify the successful synthesis of the RhCo/Fe3O4 single-atom catalyst. The mass contents of Rh, Co, C and N in the catalysts are listed in Tables S1-S2. FTIR spectroscopy was employed to characterise the chemical composition of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2a, the FTIR spectra of aromatic amines exhibit broad absorption bands at 1622–1633 cm–1, corresponding to the CC stretching vibrations of aromatic rings. Regardless of the structure of the aromatic ring bonded to nitrogen atoms, the CN stretching bands appear at about 1225 and 1242 cm–1 for aromatic polymers with one and two ortho-substituted positions on the phenyl rings, respectively [47]. Additionally, characteristic N-H stretching bands are observed in the regions of 3391–3468 cm–1 and 3315–3372 cm–1, respectively [48]. These FTIR results confirm the successful incorporation of nitrogen-containing functional groups on the catalyst surface and effective surface modification. Furthermore, the crystal structure of the catalyst was analysed using X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in the XRD patterns in Fig. 2b, the crystalline phase of Fe3O4 is clearly identifiable, while no diffraction peaks corresponding to Rh and Co crystallisation standard references are detected. This absence indicates that Rh and Co do not form crystalline phases, providing additional evidence for the successful synthesis of single-atom catalysts. To further investigate the electronic properties of FCNs, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to analyse the valence states of Rh, Co, and N. The XPS full-spectrum scan of FCN-500 is shown in Figure S4. High-resolution Rh 3d spectra of FCN-500, FCN-650 and FCN-800 were recorded, as presented in Fig. 2c and S5. For FCN-500, the energy bands of Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 were observed at 313.78 eV and 309.06 eV, respectively, confirming the presence of Rh3+ oxidation states in Rh single atoms. In contrast, the energy bands at 312.07 eV (Rh 3d3/2) and 307.35 eV (Rh 3d5/2) were assigned to Rh0 metallic states [49]. The coexistence of Rh metallic (Rh0) and oxidation states (Rh3+) is essential for the reaction process, as Rh0 is highly reactive during the initial stages because it facilitates the activation of reactants, whereas Rh3+ serves as a coordination site in subsequent stages, enhancing reactant absorption at the active site and promoting aldehyde formation [50,51]. The tunability of the electronic properties of Rh and the synergy between different oxidation states of rhodium (Rh0 and Rh3+) are essential for enhancing the activity of hydroformylation. On the basis of the XPS fitting results, the relative atomic proportions of different Rh species were calculated. The activity of the catalysts decreases sequentially from that of FCN-500 (Rh3+ 50.7 % and Rh0 49.3 %) to that of FCN-650 (Rh3+ 47.4 % and Rh0 52.6 %) to that of FCN-800 (Rh3+ 44.0 % and Rh0 56.0 %). The results indicate that under almost equivalent contents of Rh3+ and Rh0, a slight increase in Rh3+ is beneficial for improving the catalytic activity of the catalyst (Figure S6). Fig. 2d shows the Rh 3d spectra of Rh/FCN-500 without Co loading. The energy bands of Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 of the Rh3+ species are determined to be 314.61 eV and 309.95 eV, respectively, which corresponds to a 0.83 eV shift toward a higher binding energy than that of FCN-500. The Co 2p spectrum of FCN-500 displayed a binding energy of 782.42 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 of Co2+, along with weak satellite peaks characteristic of Co2+. For Co/FCN-500 catalyst, the energy bands of Co 2p3/2 were identified as 781.72 eV, attributed to Co2+ species (oxidation states), along with satellite peak at 787.24 eV (Figure S7). Overall, the Co 2p spectra of Co/FCN-500 shifted to lower binding energy compared with FCN-500, which revealed the fact that there was a charge transfer between Rh and Co species, thereby increasing the electron density in the d orbitals of Rh and forming electron-rich Rh species. The lone pair electrons of pyridinic nitrogen (pyridinic N) do not participate in the conjugated π-system, resulting in a higher localized electron density that confers Lewis basicity, enabling it to function as an electron donor. These lone pair electrons can form strong coordination bonds with transition metals in structures such as M-Nₓ, thereby anchoring metal active centres [52] . Through its electron-donating effects, pyridinic N modulates the electronic structure of metal centres, optimizing reactant adsorption and enhancing catalytic activity [53]. The lone pair electrons of graphitic nitrogen (N) integrated into the conjugated π-system of the carbon matrix engage in weak π-metal interactions with metallic species and induce a lower localized electron density at graphitic N sites. Graphitic N has a limited adsorption strength for direct metal anchoring, but it may facilitate the homogeneous dispersion and stabilization of single-atom metals by reducing their surface energy [54]. The high-resolution N 1 s spectrum was deconvoluted, revealing peaks attributed to pyridine-N (N1, 398.1 eV) and graphitic-N (N2, 401.2 eV) [55,56]. As shown in Fig. 2e, FCN-500 exhibited the highest content of N1 species. With an increase in heat treatment temperature, the proportion of N1 within the carbon matrix progressively declined, while the fraction of N2 increased correspondingly. This trend likely results from the lower thermal stability of the N1 component at elevated temperatures and the concurrent reorganisation of the carbon network. These findings highlight the tunability of nitrogen species in polymeric nitrogen-doped carbon through controlled thermal treatment. The regulation of N species significantly affects the interaction between immobilised metal active centres and carrier electrons, thereby influencing the overall catalytic activity [57]. The elevated N1 content in FCN-500 (N1 100 % and N2 0 %) significantly enhances single-atom metal immobilization. With equivalent Rh/Co loading amounts of FCN-500, FCN-650 and FCN-800, FCN-500 demonstrated superior 1-dodecene conversion (98.92 %) and TOF values (1250 h–1), confirming the crucial role of N1 in catalytic enhancement. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Evaluation of reaction kinetics The synthesised atomic-scale catalyst was employed to evaluate its catalytic performance in the hydroformylation of high-carbon α-olefins, specifically 1-dodecene. The efficiency and chemoselectivity of hydroformylation were strongly dependent on the reaction conditions. Higher temperatures promote higher reaction rates but also accelerate catalyst deactivation. Lower reaction temperatures (<100 °C) preferentially favour the formation of linear aldehydes, which is directly related to the lower activation energy of the transition state. Too low of a temperature and pressure lead to a decrease in the reaction site activity, whereas too high of a temperature and increased pressure enhance the production of branched aldehyde isomers, accompanied by significant alkene isomerization side reactions[1]. Therefore, selecting suitable reaction conditions is necessary to achieve high conversion rates and aldehyde selectivity. A temperature range of 70–120 °C and a pressure range of 2–10 MPa were selected to investigate the performance of the catalyst in the hydroformylation reaction. The catalyst containing RhCo bimetallic active centres exhibited the highest catalytic efficiency. Previous studies have demonstrated that the synergistic interaction between Rh and Co enhances catalytic activity. The incorporation of Co into Rh alters CO adsorption modes, increases both catalytic activity and selectivity toward oxygenates, and improves the efficiency of Rh active sites [58] This finding was further validated through earlier experiments, where catalysts with either Rh or Co as separate active centres were tested in the hydroformylation reaction ( Fig. 3a-b). Fig. 3c illustrates the correlation between catalytic reactivity and nitrogen species distribution. The red data points represent the conversion rate of 1-dodecene, while the blue points indicate the selectivity toward tridecanal. Notably, FCN-500 exhibited the highest TOF value of 1250 h–1 and the highest 1-dodecene conversion efficiency of 98.3 %. In comparison, FCN-650 and FCN-800 achieved conversion efficiencies of 91.2 % and 80.1 %, respectively. The pyridine nitrogen content in FCN-500, FCN-650, and FCN-800 was measured at 100 %, 45.0 %, and 19.6 %, respectively. A decrease in pyridine nitrogen content was correlated with a decrease in catalyst activity, indicating that pyridine nitrogen plays a critical role in enhancing the activity of hydroformylation. Fig. 3d-e depict the product distribution in the hydroformylation reaction and the influence of reaction parameters, such as temperature and pressure, on catalytic performance. The primary products consisted of n-tridecanal, iso-tridecanal, and minor amounts of tridecanol. The results indicate that optimal reaction conditions for achieving a high yield of aldehyde products are 8 MPa and 90 °C. During the reaction, ongoing tests were conducted to establish a kinetic profile of the catalyst's performance over time (Fig. 3f-g). Throughout the continuous reaction process, samples were periodically extracted and analysed at specific time intervals. FCN-500 consistently exhibited a superior reaction rate. Within the first 0.5 h, the olefin substrate achieved a conversion rate of 57 %, followed by a significant increase around the 1-h mark. The conversion rate then stabilised after about 2 h of reaction. FCN-650 and FCN-800 showed relatively lower substrate conversion rates while following a similar temporal trend in substrate transformation. During the reaction, catalyst selectivity exhibited a gradual decline. However, FCN-500 maintained a selectivity toward tridecanal above 95 %, while the selectivity of the other two catalysts was slightly lower. The catalytic performance of RhCo/FCN-500 has been comprehensively evaluated in hydroformylation reactions involving various olefins. Under standardized reaction conditions, the catalyst achieved 99.1 % conversion for 1-hexene and 94.5 % conversion for 1-octadecene (Table S3). Notably, both the conversion efficiency and aldehyde selectivity gradually decreased with increasing carbon chain length of the olefins. This observed trend can be attributed to the enhanced steric hindrance associated with larger molecular structures. Collectively, these results demonstrate the robust catalytic ability of RhCo/FCN-500 in facilitating hydroformylation across a spectrum of olefin substrates. 3.2.2 Magnetic separation and recycling The efficient and lossless separation of magnetic catalysts under an external magnetic field enhances their practicality in applications. After the completion of the catalytic cycle, an external magnet was used to recover the catalyst, and FCN-500 was subjected to recycling experiments to evaluate its stability over extended use. Throughout the process, the catalyst was easily adsorbed and reclaimed using magnetic separation, significantly reducing the losses typically associated with multiphase catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 4a. As shown in Fig. 4b, the initial conversion rate and aldehyde selectivity were 53.5 % and 99.1 %, respectively. The catalyst was separated from the product using a magnet and subsequently reused in repeated reaction cycles. After 10 consecutive cycles, the conversion rate and aldehyde selectivity remained at 50.3 % and 98.3 %, respectively, demonstrating that the magnetic catalyst maintained stable performance during the recycling process. Additionally, morphological characterisation of the catalyst after multiple cycles confirmed the absence of metal agglomeration (Figures S8-S9), the XPS spectra of the Rh 3d spectra of recycled FCN-500 after recycling experiments are shown in Figure S5c. Furthermore, the loading amounts of Rh and Co exhibited minimal reductions of 1.20 % and 3.17 %, respectively, after 10 cycles of recyclability experiments (Table S4). These results indicated the good stability of the catalyst. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) with supports such as metal oxides, zeolites, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), porous organic polymers (POPs), and carbon-based materials have been widely used in hydroformylation reactions. The performances of various SACs with different supports in the hydroformylation of olefins were compared and are listed in Table 1. The RhCo/FCN-500 catalyst investigated in this study demonstrated notable advantages, with a high TOF value (1250 h–1) and high aldehyde selectivity (98.6 %). 3.3 Mechanism research 3.3.1 Interaction between FCN catalyst and reactants In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy was performed to examine the surface properties of adsorbed reactants on FCN catalysts [65]. To simulate reaction conditions, FCN-500 (primarily composed of pyridine N) and FCN-800 (primarily composed of graphite N) were selected as model catalysts and exposed to a mixture of H2, CO, and atomised 1-dodecene gas at 100 °C. Subsequently, the in situ heating process was analysed using DRIFT spectroscopy. In heterogeneous hydroformylation reactions, CO adsorption and insertion are considered key steps [66]. As shown in Fig. 5a, the featured CO frequency on Rh/FCN-500 appeared at 2120 cm−1. For RhCo/FCN-500 (FCN-500), two CO frequencies were observed at 2107 and 2063 cm−1, respectively, assignable to the symmetric and asymmetric vibration of CO molecules on Rh(CO) species[67]. The band shift from 2120 to 2107 cm−1 can be ascribed to charge charge transfer from Co to Rh atoms, consistent with XPS results. The CO band at 2063 cm–1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of linearly adsorbed CO on Rh single atoms. The higher intensity of the RhCo band in FCN-500 compared to FCN-800 indicates a greater abundance of single-atom RhCo species in FCN-500. This finding suggests that CO molecules exhibit stronger interactions with Rh single atoms in FCN-500. After CO adsorption, FCN specimens were exposed to a gas mixture of H2 and 1-dodecene to conduct the in situ heating experiment, effectively simulating the actual reaction environment. The in situ DRIFT spectra were recorded at 10-min intervals. The peaks observed at 2923 cm–1, 1704 cm–1, 1456 cm–1, and 985 cm–1 correspond to the stretching vibration of C-H, the stretching vibration of CC, the scissoring vibration of C-H, and the bending vibration of C-H in 1-dodecene, respectively. Throughout the heating process, no significant shift in the absorption peaks was detected, indicating that the adsorption mechanism of the reactants remained unchanged. However, when comparing the absorption peak intensities under identical conditions, the peak at 2923 cm–1 exhibited a notably higher absorption intensity for FCN-500 than for FCN-800. This finding suggests a stronger interaction between FCN-500 and the 1-dodecene substrate molecule. These results collectively indicate that, in the interaction mode involving single-atom Rh and polymer nitrogen-doped carbon, particularly in the presence of pyridine N, the adsorption of CO and 1-dodecene molecules on active sites is enhanced. This conclusion is consistent with the experimental catalytic performance evaluations. 3.3.2 DFT calculation To gain a fundamental understanding of the catalytic activity in 1-dodecene hydroformylation, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed based on previous studies on the RhCo/FCN catalyst mechanism during hydroformylation [68]. According to prior research, the key steps in olefin hydroformylation involve olefin coordination, H2 oxidative addition, olefin insertion, CO coordination, CO insertion, and reductive elimination of aldehyde products [69,70]. A similar mechanistic framework was employed to validate the feasibility of the proposed reaction pathways. To further elucidate the role of different nitrogen species (pyridine N and graphiteN) and their potential promoting effects, three distinct catalyst structural models were constructed: RhCo-pyridicN, RhCo-graphite, and Rh-pyridicN. Based on first-principles calculations, the adsorption energy of each reactant, including H2, CO, and 1-dodecene, at the RhCo active site was determined. As shown in Fig. 6a and S10–S15, the adsorption energy of 1-dodecene molecules indicates that RhCo-pyridicN exhibits the strongest adsorption energy (–2.89 eV), exceeding that of RhCo-graphiteN and Rh-pyridicN by 0.63 eV and 1.58 eV, respectively. This suggests that RhCo-pyridicN possesses superior adsorption and activation capabilities for 1-dodecene molecules. Additionally, RhCo-pyridicN exhibits favourable CO adsorption energy (–2.69 eV), which is higher than that of RhCo graphiteN (–2.6 eV) and Rh pyridicN (–1.07 eV). Furthermore, the introduction of Co atoms significantly enhances the adsorption capacity of RhCo-pyridine N and RhCo-graphiteN for CO and H2 compared to Rh-pyridine N, which is expected to accelerate the oxidative addition of 1-dodecene molecules. A comparison between RhCo-pyridine N and RhCo-graphiteN models reveals that the variation in nitrogen species has a limited effect on CO adsorption but significantly influences the adsorption of H2 molecules. This suggests that nitrogen species play a critical role in the catalytic process of 1-dodecene hydrogenation. Further evidence was obtained from charge density calculations for the RhCo-pyridicN model (Fig. 6b). In this model, charge transfer occurs from Rh atoms to the support matrix, leading to enhanced charge connectivity across the entire support, resulting in charge redistribution and a broader positive charge state. The charge density exhibits a wider and stronger distribution, facilitating electron transfer and generating a higher binding energy with substrate molecules. In contrast, the charge distribution in RhCo-graphiteN and Rh-pyridicN is primarily localised around individual atoms, resulting in weaker interactions with the carrier. This leads to lower electron accumulation near the carrier region and reduced adsorption strength for substrate molecules in these configurations. Further DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the reaction pathways and free energy barriers [71]. The hydroformylation reaction is divided into three main steps: the activation and dissociation of H2 at the RhCo-N site, the attack of H atoms on 1-dodecene along the CC bond to generate hydrides bonded to the RhCo site, and CO insertion from the side, leading to the formation of n-tridecanal and iso-tridecanal (Fig. 6c). Fig. 6d illustrates the Gibbs free energy diagram, depicting the energy variation path for the RhCo-pyridicN and RhCo-graphiteN models in 1-dodecene hydroformylation. In the RhCo-pyridicN model, the activation energies of TS1 and TS3 are 0.186 eV and 0.181 eV, respectively, both lower than the activation energy of TS2 (0.377 eV). A similar trend is observed in the RhCo-graphiteN model, confirming that CO insertion is the rate-determining step in the hydroformylation process. Additionally, a comparison of the transition state activation energies between the RhCo-pyridincN and RhCo-graphiteN models indicates that the energy barrier of TS1 in the RhCo-graphiteN model is 0.235 eV, which is 0.049 eV higher than that of RhCo-pyridincN. The RhCo-pyridicN model exhibits lower free energy barriers in three critical steps: H2 oxidation, addition, and CO insertion, suggesting that the oxidation of 1-dodecene occurs more readily on the RhCo-pyridicN surface, aligning with previous experimental findings. Overall, the DFT simulations indicate that the RhCo-pyridine N site in SACs effectively lowers the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining step, thereby facilitating the hydrogenation process. The interaction mode between RhCo-pyridine N contributes to the regulation of electron density at the single-atom active centres, reducing the free energy barrier and promoting reaction progression [72]. Under identical metal loading conditions, the catalytic active centre can be modulated by adjusting the type of N species, providing a valuable model for the design of polymer nitrogen-carbon-loaded single-atom catalysts. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a facile synthesis of a magnetic single-atom catalyst with exceptional catalytic performance in the hydroformylation of α-olefins was reported. The catalyst demonstrated significant magnetic separation properties, facilitating efficient recovery and reuse. The influence of the RhCo-N interaction mode on catalytic performance was investigated under identical Rh and Co single-atom loadings. The RhCo-pyridine N configuration enhanced 1-dodecene hydroformylation, achieving a conversion efficiency of 98.3 % and selectivity (98.6 %) towards tridecanal. Additionally, catalyst loss was minimised through magnetic separation, and the recovery performance remained stable after 10 reuse cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed that tuning the type of N species regulates the adsorption energy of reactants at single-atom active centres, thereby improving reactant adsorption and activation. Density functional theory simulations confirmed that CO insertion into the CC bond represents the highest free energy barrier and the rate-determining step in hydroformylation. The RhCo-pyridine N configuration effectively lowers the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining step and hydrogenation, leading to enhanced substrate reactivity. This study not only broadens the industrial application potential of magnetic multiphase catalysts but also provides deeper insights into the interaction between metal active centres and supports. These findings offer a foundation for the rational structural design of single-atom catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Regulating the hydroformylation capacity of heterogeneous catalysts is essential for efficiently converting higher olefins into aldehydes. In this study, a magnetic single-atom rhodium-cobalt-based catalyst (RhCo SACs) was synthesised by modifying Fe3O4 with polymerised carbon nitride. Maintaining a constant metal single-atom loading, the catalytic activity in 1-dodecene hydroformylation was modulated by adjusting the type of N species in the support. The distribution of single atoms and valence states was characterised. At the same time, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to evaluate substrate binding energies and reaction-free energy barriers, providing insights into reaction mechanisms and pathways. The RhCo-pyridinic N configuration lowered the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining and hydrogenation steps, enhancing substrate reaction activity. Compared to RhCo-graphitic N, RhCo-pyridinic N demonstrated superior performance, achieving a 1-dodecene conversion rate of 98.3 % and aldehyde selectivity of 98.6 %. Furthermore, the catalyst was magnetically recovered without loss of activity or mass and maintained stable performance over 10 reuse cycles. These findings present a novel and efficient strategy for the precise design of magnetic single-atom catalysts with potential practical applications in the hydroformylation of high-carbon olefins.
